Federated Learning with Server Learning: Enhancing Performance for Non-IID Data

Van Sy Mai, Richard J. La, Tao Zhang V. S. Mai and T. Zhang are with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), Gaithersburg, MD 20899, USA. Email: {vansy.mai, tao.zhang}@nist.gov. R.J. La is with NIST and the University of Maryland, College Park, MD 20742, USA. Email: hyongla@umd.edu. Any mention of commercial products in this paper is for information only; it does not imply any recommendation or endorsement by NIST. U.S. Government work not protected by U.S. copyright
Abstract

Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a means of distributed learning using local data stored at clients with a coordinating server. Recent studies showed that FL can suffer from poor performance and slower convergence when training data at clients are not independent and identically distributed. Here we consider a new complementary approach to mitigating this performance degradation by allowing the server to perform auxiliary learning from a small dataset. Our analysis and experiments show that this new approach can achieve significant improvements in both model accuracy and convergence time even when the server dataset is small and its distribution differs from that of the aggregated data from all clients.

I Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) is a recent paradigm in which multiple clients collaborate under the coordination of a central server to train machine learning (ML) models [13]. A key advantage is that clients need not send their local data to any central sever or share their data with each other. Performing learning where the data is generated (or collected) is becoming necessary as a large and growing amount of data is created at the network edge and cannot all be forwarded to any central location due to many factors such as network capacity constraints, latency requirements, and data privacy concerns [4].

In its basic form, FL trains a global model for all clients based on the following high-level iterative procedure. At each global round: 1) the central server selects a subset of clients and shares the current global model with them, 2) each selected client updates the model using only its local data and forwards the updated model to the central server, and 3) the central server aggregates the updated local models from the clients to update the global model. This process is repeated until certain convergence criteria are satisfied.

Background: Conventional FL techniques, such as the well-known Federated Averaging (FedAvg) algorithm [22], carry out model aggregation by averaging the model parameters received from the clients. This performs well when clients have access to independent and identically distributed (IID) training samples. In practice, however, the local data available to the clients often do not satisfy this IID assumption for different reasons. For instance, clients may collect data from different sources, using different tools, under different conditions, or only have access to partial or biased data, which can cause the distributions of the samples or features at different clients to differ considerably. Such divergences are also referred to as drifts or shifts, and can take different forms [13].

Large divergences can cause conventional FL techniques to suffer from poor model performance and slow training convergence [6, 8, 12, 14, 18, 33]. For example, feature divergence, where the distributions of features differ at different clients, may cause local models to focus on different features or even use different feature representations. Non-IID training data can also cause clients to optimize their local models toward local optima that can differ significantly from global optima. This can further cause the weights of clientsâ€™ local models to diverge [21, 33]. As a result, simply averaging local models may not move the aggregated model toward a global optimum.

Recently, growing efforts have been devoted to improving FL performance for non-IID data. The following are several representative categories of approaches.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Personalization: Clients personalize their local models to perform well on their local data [6, 11, 16, 17, 26]. Personalization can be for individual clients or groups of clients (e.g., clients that have similar training data or contribute similar model updates to the server) [3] [9]. Many real-world applications, however, desire a common model for all clients. For example, consider autonomous vehicles (AVs) in different geographical regions learning to recognize stop signs. The snow-covered stop signs in northeast United States can look very different from those along the sunny southern country roads. Since cars can travel anywhere, they will benefit from a model that can work well everywhere.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Changing how clients learn or contribute: Several approaches aim to better align the objectives of clients that can diverge due to non-IID training data, e.g.,Â [24, 30]. Clients may use Batch Normalization to alleviate local model divergence caused by non-IID data [19]. Batch Normalization [10] has been used in deep learning to mitigate the impact of domain shifts (i.e., differences between training data distribution and test data distribution). Various methods have also been proposed to choose a subset of the clients to participate in each round of FL to counterbalance distribution shifts [25, 32].

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Changing how the server aggregates local models: This approach alters the aggregation method of local models based on, e.g., their distances to an estimated global model baseline [28], or additional client states or control variates [14].

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Lifelong learning techniques: These techniques treat the learning at each client as a separate task and learn these tasks sequentially using a single model without forgetting the previously learned tasks [13].

Motivation: Our main observation is that these existing FL algorithms do not consider the central server as a learner or assume that the server has no training data. In practice, however, the server can and often have access to some training data. For example, the server may receive data from sensors and testing devices that do not participate in the learning process. It may have synthetic data obtained from simulation (or emulation) and digital twins. The server may also receive some raw data directly from the clients; this is often required to, for example, support system monitoring and diagnosis.

Consider again AVs, as an example, which need ML models to recognize objects. Today, two main sources of data are used to train and test such models. First, test vehicles are used to scout selected areas to collect real-world data. Note that this typically imposes no privacy concerns. It, however, may require large fleets of test vehicles, take years to accomplish, incur heavy costs, and yet still fail to collect enough data to cover the vast range of possible learning needs [31]. Therefore, the AV industry is increasingly relying on a second source of data â€“ synthetic data, typically generated in the cloud â€“ to extend model training and testing scopes. Going forward, when some AVs participate in FL, a small fleet of test vehicles, which may not all participate in FL, can still be used to collect and send data to the server to compensate the data that the FL clients can collect.

Sharing a common IID training dataset with all clients (so that each client will train its local model on its local data plus this common dataset) has been shown to improve FL performance with non-IID data [13, 17, 33]. But, this method, which we refer to as FL with data sharing or simply data sharing, also increases clientsâ€™ workload, making them less suitable for resource-constrained devices. More importantly, it is often impractical for clients to share data with each other due to privacy concerns, network bandwidth constraints, and latency requirements. We will show that it is unnecessary to share such common datasets among clients, as comparable or better performance can be achieved by having the server learn from the same dataset.

Several recent works have considered server learning with some centralized data, e.g., hybrid training [27], mixed FL [1], and FL with server learningÂ [20]. However, [27] analyzes only the case where both clientsâ€™ data and server data are IID and their algorithm requires all clients to participate in every round. Similarly, [1] assumes IID client data and considers serverâ€™s role as a regularizer. In contrast, [20] focuses on FL with non-IID client data. In this paper, we build upon our work in [20] to study the idea of using server learning to enhance FL on non-IID data and provide both analytical and experimental results showing that this approach can be effective under certain conditions. Therefore, the primary focus of our study and reported analysis are fundamentally different from those in [1] and [27].

Contributions: We consider a new FL algorithm that incorporates server learning to improve performance on non-IID data. Specifically, the server collects a small amount of data, learns from it, and distills the knowledge into the global model incrementally during the FL process. We refer to this method as Federated Learning with Server Learning (FSL). Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet Through our analysis and experimental studies, we show that FSL can significantly improve the performance in both final accuracy and convergence time when clients have non-IID data. Also, only a small amount of data is needed at the server for FSL to improve performance, even when the server data distribution deviates from that of the aggregated data stored at the clients. As expected, the training performance improves as such distribution divergence diminishes.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet By incorporating server learning with FL in an incremental fashion, we will demonstrate that FSL significantly accelerates the learning process when the current model is far from any (locally) optimal model.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet FSL is simple and can be tuned relatively easily, even when the server dataset is relatively small. Compared to FL, FSL adds only a local learning component to the server and does not affect the clients. Thus, FSL has the same per-round communication overhead as FL while practically requiring to tune only one additional parameter, which is the weight given to serverâ€™s loss function. Our experimental studies show that the performance improvement of FSL remains significant for a relatively large range of this weight.

In our experiments, FSL consistently outperforms the data sharing method in [33], suggesting that sharing common datasets with clients might be unnecessary. We also demonstrate that by employing a small amount of data from either a few clients or other data sources (including synthetic data) for server learning, FSL can achieve similar (and often better) performance compared to FedDyn [7] and SCAFFOLD [14], while enjoying a significant boost in learning rate at the beginning.

Preliminary results of this paper appeared in [20], where only the main algorithm and limited experimental results using IID server data were reported. In this paper, we provide a theoretical analysis of FSL and more extensive experimental evaluations, including a comparison with SCAFFOLD algorithm using non-IID server data.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The problem formulation and our algorithm are given in Â§Â II. Main convergence results are presented in Â§Â III, followed by experimental evaluations in Â§Â IV. Conclusions are given in Â§Â V. All the proofs and additional numerical results can be found in our technical report in AppendicesÂ A andÂ B, respectively.

II Problem Formulation and Our Approach

In this section, we first present our problem formulation in connection with the data sharing approach, and then delineate the FSL algorithm aimed at coping with non-IID data.

II-B FSL Algorithm

We assume that the server has access to dataset ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} and will augment FL with what the server learns over ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0}. As stated earlier, we refer to this approach as Federated Learning with Server Learning or FSL.

There are several ways to incorporate server learning (SL) into FL. One is to treat the server as a regular client that participates in every round of FL process [29]: During each global round, the server updates the current global model using ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} and then aggregates it with the updated models reported by the clients. We call this approach non-incremental SL. One issue with non-incremental SL is that the weight for the server would be very small when n0â‰ªnmuch-less-thansubscriptğ‘›0ğ‘›n_{0}\ll n, which means that the serverâ€™s contributions, based on its learning from ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0}, to the global model will be minor. Moreover, this approach fails to exploit the good quality of ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0}, especially when its distribution is close to that of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}. This issue can be partially alleviated by increasing the weight given to the serverâ€™s model in the aggregation step.

These observations motivate us to consider an incremental learning scheme in which the server performs additional learning over dataset ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} based on the aggregated model, as shown in AlgorithmÂ 1 below in more detail. In particular, lines 1â€“9 of AlgorithmÂ 1 are the same as in a conventional FL algorithm [22], where in each global round tğ‘¡t, each selected client iğ‘–i (1) receives the current global model xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} from the server, (2) performs Kğ¾K steps of the Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) algorithm using its local data ğ’Ÿisubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘–\mathcal{D}_{i} (LocalSGD) with learning rate Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l}, and (3) returns to the server its update Î”t(i)superscriptsubscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–\Delta_{t}^{(i)}. The server then combines its current model xtsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡x_{t} with the updates from the clients using some weight Î·g>0subscriptğœ‚ğ‘”0\eta_{g}>0 (linesÂ 8â€“9). It then uses the resulting updated model to learn locally by performing K0subscriptğ¾0K_{0} steps of LocalSGD with learning rate Î³â€‹Î·0ğ›¾subscriptğœ‚0\gamma\eta_{0} (lineÂ 10). As one can see, our approach has the same computation and communication costs at the clients as the usual FL framework.

Note that our algorithm is similar to the incremental (stochastic) gradient method, which has been shown to be much faster than the non-incremental gradient method when the model is far from a (locally) optimal point [2]. While FL with local SGD also works in an incremental fashion, it often needs small learning rates, hence longer learning times, to ensure convergence when the distribution of clientsâ€™ data is heterogeneous.

Before presenting a formal analysis and experimental results, let us provide some insights into FSL. First, when the distributions of ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} and ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} are close, serverâ€™s loss function f0subscriptğ‘“0f_{0} will be similar to the overall loss function Fğ¹F in (1). Consequently, if the current model is far from an optimal point, the gradient âˆ‡f0âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0\nabla f_{0} will track the global gradient âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla F, even when individual clientsâ€™ gradients âˆ‡fiâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\nabla f_{i} do not follow âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla F closely. Therefore, when the updated model obtained by aggregating clientsâ€™ updated models does not make (much) progress, âˆ‡f0âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0\nabla f_{0} will help improve the updated model. In fact, it turns out that significant improvements can still be achieved even when the distributions of ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} and ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} are not very similar as long as their difference is small in relation to the non-IIDness of clientsâ€™ data. We will elaborate on these points in the following section.

III Convergence Results

We first show in subsectionÂ III-A that SL can be viewed as a correction step for FL in the case of non-IID training data. Then the main convergence results are provided in subsectionÂ III-B.

III-A SL as Corrections to FL When Far from Convergence

In order to simplify our discussion presented in this subsection which provides key intuition behind our approach, assume that the server can compute gradient âˆ‡f0â€‹(x)âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¥\nabla f_{0}(x), xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, and consider the usual gradient descent (GD) method for SL. First, consider a single update carried out by the server using GD, starting with some model w0subscriptğ‘¤0w_{0}, i.e., w1=w0âˆ’Î·0â€‹âˆ‡f0â€‹(w0)subscriptğ‘¤1subscriptğ‘¤0subscriptğœ‚0âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘¤0w_{1}=w_{0}-\eta_{0}\nabla f_{0}(w_{0}). Suppose that âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla F is Lipschitz continuous with parameter Lğ¿L.222This assumption is standard in FL and often holds when training neural networks. We will state this assumption formally in SectionÂ III-B. Then,

First, the error â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(w0)âˆ’âˆ‡f0â€‹(w0)â€–2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¤0âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘¤02\|\nabla F(w_{0})-\nabla f_{0}(w_{0})\|^{2} in general depends on relationship between the serverâ€™s dataset ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} and the aggregate dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}; the more dissimilar ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} is to ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, the larger the error and thus the smaller the improvement. As an example, consider ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} consisting of IID samples. III-B Convergence Analysis

In this subsection, we study the convergence properties of FSL. Specifically, we will prove that, under suitable conditions on step sizes, FSL converges to a neighborhood of a stationary point of the following modified loss function

F~=11+Î³â€‹F+Î³1+Î³â€‹f0~ğ¹11ğ›¾ğ¹ğ›¾1ğ›¾subscriptğ‘“0\tilde{F}=\textstyle\frac{1}{1+\gamma}F+\frac{\gamma}{1+\gamma}f_{0}

which is simply the normalized version of that in (5), where the weight Î³>0ğ›¾0\gamma>0 is chosen by the server. The value of Î³ğ›¾\gamma should depend on the quality of serverâ€™s dataset ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0}: when the distribution of ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} is close to that of ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}, a larger value would offer greater benefits. But, our analysis presented below does not assume that their distributions are close. Also, our experimental results demonstrate that the FSL algorithm can deliver significant benefits even when the two distributions differ considerably (see SectionÂ IV)

First, we state several assumptions under which our analysis of AlgorithmÂ 1 is carried out.

Assumption 1.

The server and clientâ€™s local loss functions {fi}i=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘–0ğ‘\{f_{i}\}_{i=0}^{N} are Lğ¿L-smooth on â„dsuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘\mathbb{R}^{d}.

This assumption is standard in the literature and is often satisfied in practice. It also implies that the global loss functions Fğ¹F and F~~ğ¹\tilde{F} are Lğ¿L-smooth. The second assumption is used to bound the gradient dissimilarity caused by clientsâ€™ non-IID data; see, e.g., [23].

Assumption 2.

There exists a finite constant GğºG such that 1Nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[N]â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(x)â€–2â‰¤G21ğ‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¥2superscriptğº2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in[N]}\|\nabla f_{i}(x)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2}\leq G^{2} for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

Here, GğºG bounds the average disparity between the gradients of clientsâ€™ loss functions and the empirical loss caused by non-IID samples at the clients; the IID case corresponds to Gâ†’0â†’ğº0G\to 0. Similarly, when the distributions of ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} and ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} are different, there can be a discrepancy between âˆ‡f0âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0\nabla f_{0} and âˆ‡Fâˆ‡ğ¹\nabla F. We use the following assumption to characterize the quality of server dataset ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0}.

Assumption 3.

There exists a finite constant Î¾Â¯Â¯ğœ‰\bar{\xi} such that â€–âˆ‡f0â€‹(x)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(x)â€–2â‰¤Î¾Â¯2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0ğ‘¥âˆ‡ğ¹ğ‘¥2superscriptÂ¯ğœ‰2\|\nabla f_{0}(x)-\nabla F(x)\|^{2}\leq\bar{\xi}^{2} for all xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.

This assumption does not imply that the server data distribution is similar to that of the clientsâ€™ aggregate data (although this would be an ideal situation). In other words, Î¾Â¯2superscriptÂ¯ğœ‰2\bar{\xi}^{2} is not necessarily small, and our analysis presented below examines how this bound affects the performance of FSL.

Note that the uniform bounds in AssumptionsÂ 2 and 3 are introduced to simplify presentation; what we need in our analysis is that the bounds hold for the sequence {xt}tâ‰¥0subscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘¡0\{x_{t}\}_{t\geq 0} generated by our algorithm. This holds, for example, when {xt}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\{x_{t}\} is bounded. Although those bounds are usually unknown, they quantify the extent of non-IIDness in clientsâ€™ and serverâ€™s data and facilitate our analysis.

Finally, we assume that the clients and the server can obtain unbiased noisy estimates of the gradient of their local loss functions for updating their local models.This assumption is also standard in stochastic optimization.

Assumption 4.

All clients iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[N] and the server (i=0ğ‘–0i=0) have access to unbiased estimates gisubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–g_{i} of âˆ‡fiâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–\nabla f_{i} with variance bounded by Ïƒi2superscriptsubscriptğœğ‘–2\sigma_{i}^{2}. For simplicity, we further assume that Ïƒi=Ïƒsubscriptğœğ‘–ğœ\sigma_{i}=\sigma for all iâˆˆ[N]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘i\in[N].

Here, Ïƒisubscriptğœğ‘–\sigma_{i} only bounds the variance of noisy estimates for the clients and the server. Note that it is not uncommon in practice that the server has enough computing capability so that it can obtain gradient estimates with small variance. For example, when n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} is sufficiently small, the server may utilize all samples to compute the exact gradient for each update, in which case we have Ïƒ0=0subscriptğœ00\sigma_{0}=0.

Let us now briefly describe the idea to prove the convergence of FSL. For the special case when N=1ğ‘1N=1, K=1ğ¾1K=1, and Ïƒi=0subscriptğœğ‘–0\sigma_{i}=0, FSL simply reduces to the incremental gradient method. For a general case, we can relate the sequence {xt}subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡\{x_{t}\} generated by our algorithm to that of a centralized incremental stochastic gradient method applied to the global loss function F~~ğ¹\tilde{F}, where the difference between the two is caused by client sampling and local learning steps. As a result, by choosing step sizes sufficiently small in connection with the bounds in AssumptionsÂ 1â€“4, we can bound such differences and relate the convergence of the two algorithms.

Our first result below demonstrates the progress in one global round of FSL, which resembles that of a centralized stochastic gradient algorithm. Finally, let us remark on the optimality of the original loss. Since â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(xt)â€–2â‰¤(1+Î³)â€‹â€–âˆ‡F~â€‹(xt)â€–2+Î³1+Î³â€‹Î¾Â¯2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡21ğ›¾superscriptnormâˆ‡~ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2ğ›¾1ğ›¾superscriptÂ¯ğœ‰2\|\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2}\leq(1+\gamma)\|\nabla\tilde{F}(x_{t})\|^{2}+\frac{\gamma}{1+\gamma}\bar{\xi}^{2}, it follows that mintâ‰¤Tâˆ’1â¡ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(xt)â€–2â‰¤(1+Î³)â€‹â„°T+Î³1+Î³â€‹Î¾Â¯2subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘‡1ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡21ğ›¾subscriptâ„°ğ‘‡ğ›¾1ğ›¾superscriptÂ¯ğœ‰2\min_{t\leq T-1}{\mathbb{E}}\|\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2}\leq(1+\gamma)\mathcal{E}_{T}+\frac{\gamma}{1+\gamma}\bar{\xi}^{2}. Here, â„°Tsubscriptâ„°ğ‘‡\mathcal{E}_{T} can be bounded using CorollaryÂ 1, while the second term affects the neighborhood to which the model converges. Thus, in principle, one should select Î³ğ›¾\gamma judiciously to trade off between these two terms. However, we show numerically in the next section that this can be done fairly easily.

IV Experimental Results

We now illustrate the benefits of FSL through experiments using two datasets CIFAR-10 [15] and EMNIST [5].

IV-A Setup

Data and Model: For CIFAR-10 and EMNIST, we use, respectively, 50k samples with 10 label classes and 108k samples with 45 label classes for training. Each dataset also has 10k samples for testing. For simplicity, we partition the nnn training samples roughly evenly among NNN clients so that each clientÂ iii has ni=nNsubscriptninNn_{i}\!=\!\frac{n}{N} samples of CCC label classes. Each client will have niCsubscriptniC\frac{n_{i}}{C} samples per label class, selected uniformly at random without replacement from training data. We vary CCC to study the effect of client data heterogeneity â€“ smaller CCC represents more non-IID client data. We use neural networks with two convolutional layers and two dense hidden layers and cross-entropy as the loss function for training; see AppendixÂ B-A for further details.

Methods We compare our approach FSL against (1) Federated Learning FedAvg (FL) [22], (2) FL combined with Data Sharing (DS) [33] that requires sharing among all clients a common dataset comprising samples uniformly distributed over classes, (3) FedDyn [7] which requires additional client storage to retain their state, and (4) SCAFFOLD [14] that doubles communication overheads compared to other methods. For FSL, we assume that the server dataset ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} has n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} samples taken from the training data. To facilitate comparison, we use ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} as the dataset shared among clients in DS. We also tested FSL with non-incremental SL (Â§Â II), but put its results in AppendixÂ B-B2 for reference as it underperforms FSL.

Implementation Each client chosen by the server at each round trains its local model for EcsubscriptEcE_{c} epochs using local data with batch size BBB. In FSL, the server also updates its model for EssubscriptEsE_{s} epochs in each round using batch size B0subscriptB0B_{0}. Here, we fix Ec=1subscriptEc1E_{c}=1, Es=âŒˆnNâ€‹n0â€‹EcâŒ‰subscriptEsnNsubscriptn0subscriptEcE_{s}=\lceil\frac{n}{Nn_{0}}E_{c}\rceil, B0=BsubscriptB0BB_{0}=B, Î·g=SsubscriptÎ·gS\eta_{g}=\sqrt{S}, and set Î·0=Sâ€‹Î·lâ€‹K/K0subscriptÎ·0SsubscriptÎ·lKsubscriptK0\eta_{0}=\sqrt{S}\eta_{l}K/K_{0}.

Evaluations We run all algorithms for T=1,000ğ‘‡1000T=1,000 rounds, and compare their test accuracy (averaged using a rolling window of size 20) and convergence time measured by rise time, which we define as the first time the test accuracy reaches 90%percent9090\% of the final accuracy. The reported numbers are the averages of 3 runs.

We consider the following two scenarios (which mimic the settings in [33] and [14], respectively): (1) Nğ‘N is small, and server data are IID and of small size compared to clientâ€™s data, and (2) Nğ‘N is large, server data are non-IID, and client data size is relatively small.

IV-B Scenario 1

Consider (N,ni,n0)=(10,5000,500)ğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘›0105000500(N,n_{i},n_{0})=(10,5000,500) for CIFAR-10 and (45,2400,225)452400225(45,2400,225) for EMNIST. Here, ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} has roughly n0Csubscriptğ‘›0ğ¶\frac{n_{0}}{C} samples per label class, sampled without replacement from ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D}. We study the role of different parameters in FSL and compare it against FL and DS. Both DS and FSL use a pretrain step where the server trains its local model using SGD with learning rate of 0.010.010.01 for 500500500 epochs over its data ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} with batch size BğµB. We varied Î³âˆˆ{Nâ€‹n0n,0.5,1,1.5,2}ğ›¾ğ‘subscriptğ‘›0ğ‘›0.511.52\gamma\in\{\frac{Nn_{0}}{n},0.5,1,1.5,2\}; note that when Î³=Nâ€‹n0nğ›¾ğ‘subscriptğ‘›0ğ‘›\gamma=\frac{Nn_{0}}{n}, FSL has the same (global) objective as DS.

Effects of Client Data Distributions: Fig.Â 1 shows the test accuracy as we vary CCC to create different levels of non-IIDness. We have the following observations.

First, all algorithms achieve a similar final accuracy in the IID case (C=45C45C=45 for EMNIST and C=10C10C=10 for CIFAR-10). But, when client data become more non-IID as CCC decreases, FL suffers significantly in both accuracy and convergence time, which is expected and well reported in the literature. Second, DS greatly improves over FL, but has a similar convergence property: slower learning with wide oscillations. This is to be expected as DS is essentially FL where each client has an additional small set of shared data. Third, in all cases, FSL provides the highest accuracy and fastest convergence with considerable acceleration at the beginning and much smaller oscillations in accuracy, thanks to only a small dataset at the server (which is about 0.21%percent0.210.21\% of training data for EMNIST and 1%percent11\% for CIFAR-10). Fourth, FSL performs fairly consistently for a range of Î³Î³\gamma values, suggesting that fine tuning might be unnecessary. Finally, although we use a pretrained model for FSL and DS but not FL, we show in AppendixÂ B-B1 that similar observations can be obtained when FSL, DS, and FL all use the same initial model. In fact, FSL provides more significant acceleration, even in the IID cases, whereas DS offers little to no benefits over FL.

Benefits of Server Learning: Fig.Â 2 plots the accuracy and rise time of FSL when varying the weight Î³ğ›¾\gamma, learning rate Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l}, and server data size n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0}.

Role of Î³ğ›¾\gamma: First, in general, increasing Î³ğ›¾\gamma from 00 improves the accuracy and convergence time significantly compared to DS. The improvement is more pronounced when comparing to FL. Second, such improvements remain significant over a wide range of Î³ğ›¾\gamma values. For example, Î³ğ›¾\gamma over [0.5,1.5]0.51.5[0.5,1.5] provides similar performance for all considered local learning rates Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l}, server data sizes n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0}, and for both datasets. For CIFAR-10, it appears that a smaller Î³ğ›¾\gamma provides better results, while a large value may slightly degrade the performance; the opposite holds true for EMNIST (except when C=1ğ¶1C=1 and Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l} is large, increasing Î³>1ğ›¾1\gamma>1 actually decreases the accuracy). This can be attributed to the fact that the client data are more non-IID and server samples are more dissimilar in CIFAR-10 than in EMNIST; see the cases C=2ğ¶2C=2 and C=5ğ¶5C=5 in Fig.Â 1.

Server data size: First, with a small (good quality) dataset, the server can already have a pretrained model much better than random initialization. Second, it is clear that increasing the server data size helps improve FSL further. Here, the accuracy improvement is greater for CIFAR-10 than EMNIST. The rise time improvement is significant when Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l} is small and diminishes for larger Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l}. Note that increasing the local learning rate Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l} also increases the serverâ€™s effective learning rate, which is Î³â€‹Î·0=Î³â€‹Î·lâ€‹Sğ›¾subscriptğœ‚0ğ›¾subscriptğœ‚ğ‘™ğ‘†\gamma\eta_{0}=\gamma\eta_{l}\sqrt{S}.

IV-C Scenario 2

Consider (N,ni)=ğ‘subscriptğ‘›ğ‘–absent(N,n_{i})= (1000, 50) for CIFAR-10 and (450, 240) for EMNIST. Unlike in Scenario 1, we now consider two different sources of data for the server.

Data from a few clients

The server obtains data only from a subset of cğ‘c clients,555These clients can be, for example, test vehicles in our AV example; here they are sampled without replacement once prior to training for simplicity. each contributing sğ‘ s samples (selected uniformly at random without replacement). Here (c,s,n0)=(10,50,500)ğ‘ğ‘ subscriptğ‘›01050500(c,s,n_{0})=(10,50,500) for CIFAR-10 and (9,50,450)950450(9,50,450) for EMNIST. Note that the server data is imbalanced and non-IID (likely missing one or more label classes when C=1ğ¶1C=1).

Data from other source(s)

For EMNIST, we provide the server n0=675subscriptğ‘›0675n_{0}=675 synthetic examples by generating for each label class 15 images of the corresponding letter or number using a cursive font with 5 rotation angles {âˆ’20,âˆ’10,0,10,20}201001020\{-20,-10,0,10,20\} and 3 sizes;666To generate synthetic data, we first plot each character or number in a 2 inch Ã—\times 2 inch figure using font sizes {100,110,120}100110120\{100,110,120\} in points with each point equal to 1/721721/72 inch, and then resize it to a 28 pixel Ã—\times 28 pixel figure. see Fig.Â 3 for a comparison of this synthetic data and EMNIST. For CIFAR-10, we collect n0=504subscriptğ‘›0504n_{0}=504 images from the dataset STL-10 with 9 similar label classes as in CIFAR-10, each with 56 examples;777STL-10 images were acquired from labeled examples on ImageNet; data available at: https://cs.stanford.edu/âˆ¼similar-to\simacoates/stl10/ see Fig.Â 4 for an illustration of this data, and note that the class frog is absent in STL-10. We refer to our algorithm in this case as FSLsyn. Our goal with FSLsyn is to examine the benefits of server learning when it is performed on data with a significantly different distribution than that of clientsâ€™ data.

We compare FSL and FSLsyn (without using a pretrained model) against SCAFFOLD and FedDyn when S=âŒˆN/100âŒ‰ğ‘†ğ‘100S=\lceil N/100\rceil. We use Î·g=Ssubscriptğœ‚ğ‘”ğ‘†\eta_{g}=\sqrt{S} for FSL, FSLsyn, and SCAFFOLD. Fig.Â 5 shows the test accuracy after T=1,000ğ‘‡1000T=1,000 rounds with varying learning rate Î·lsubscriptğœ‚ğ‘™\eta_{l} and non-IIDness Cğ¶C. Here, we fix the weight Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma\!=\!1 in FSL and FSLsyn and regularization parameter Î±=0.01ğ›¼0.01\alpha=0.01 in FedDyn; better performance can be obtained by tuning these parameters as we will show later. First, it shows that, compared to SCAFFOLD and FedDyn, our algorithms FSL and FSLsyn have comparable overall accuracy for EMNIST and much better for CIFAR-10, especially in very non-IID cases, even without tuning Î³ğ›¾\gamma. The heatmap also suggests that it is fairly easy to select learning rates for FSL and FSLsyn. The results further indicate that using server learning with synthetic or other â€˜goodâ€™ sources of data can provide significant benefits. In fact, FSLsyn has comparable performance to FSL for EMNIST and slightly worse performance for CIFAR-10 (but still better than FedDyn and SCAFFOLD in this case). Additional experimental results reported in FiguresÂ 10 and 11 in AppendixÂ B-B4 also show that FSL and FSLsyn have faster rise times in most cases. Note that our algorithm can be improved further by having more (and better) data for server learning and using a pretraining step.

Finally, Table 1 shows that both the quantity and the quality of serverâ€™s data ğ’Ÿ0subscriptğ’Ÿ0\mathcal{D}_{0} affect the performance of FSL. These results are obtained with CIFAR-10 when clientsâ€™ data is highly non-IID with C=2ğ¶2C=2, and we pick the learning rates according to the highest accuracy given in Fig.Â 5. We also fine-tune the regularization parameter of FedDyn with Î±âˆˆ{0.01,0.05,0.1,0.5}ğ›¼0.010.050.10.5\alpha\in\{0.01,0.05,0.1,0.5\} following [7] and the server weight Î³âˆˆ{0.6,0.8,1.0,1.2}ğ›¾0.60.81.01.2\gamma\in\{0.6,0.8,1.0,1.2\} in FSL and FSLsyn â€“ we report the best numbers and skip SCAFFOLD as it underperforms FedDyn. Moreover, we vary the server data size n0âˆˆ{250,500}subscriptğ‘›0250500n_{0}\in\{250,500\} for FSL, and n0âˆˆ{504,720}subscriptğ‘›0504720n_{0}\in\{504,720\} for FSLsyn. Both the rise time and the accuracy improve as n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} increases, with FSL featuring a more significant improvement since the serverâ€™s data are more similar to the clientsâ€™ data compared to synthetic data (see Fig.Â 4). In addition, both of our algorithms require a significantly smaller number of global rounds to reach 0.5 accuracy, showcasing the benefit of server learning. It is also interesting to note that FSL with n0=250subscriptğ‘›0250n_{0}=250 is still slightly better than FSLsyn with n0=720subscriptğ‘›0720n_{0}=720, confirming that the synthetic data are likely taken from a different distribution.

V Conclusions

We considered a new approach to mitigate the performance degradation of FL on non-IID data. Our approach augments FL with server learning using a small dataset, and thus is complementary in that it can be utilized in conjunction with other existing approaches in the literature. Our analysis and experiments revealed that FSL can offer significant improvements in terms of accuracy and convergence time over conventional FL algorithms, even when the server dataset is relatively small. As expected, the improvements depend not only on server data size but also on the divergence between its distribution and that of the aggregate training data. The improvements are higher when the distributional divergence is smaller. We are currently exploring the issue of choosing a suitable dataset for the server learning and the relationship between the performance improvements and the server data size/the distributional divergence.

A-F Special Cases

Let us show here that our FSL approach includes FedAvg and centralized SGD as special cases.

FedAvg as a Special Case

Clearly, FedAvg is the special case of our formulation with Î³â†’0â†’ğ›¾0\gamma\to 0, i.e., there is no server learning. Take Corollary 3.7, for example, although the bound on the RHS is by no means tight, itâ€™s clear that using a positive Î³ğ›¾\gamma will lower RHS (provided Î¾Â¯Â¯ğœ‰\bar{\xi} small compared to GğºG), especially the coefficient of the dominant error term 1T1ğ‘‡\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}} in the bound, which is D~0+G2(1+Î³)2subscript~ğ·0superscriptğº2superscript1ğ›¾2\tilde{D}_{0}+\frac{G^{2}}{(1+\gamma)^{2}}. Note also that D~0=ğ’ªâ€‹(D01+Î³)subscript~ğ·0ğ’ªsubscriptğ·01ğ›¾\tilde{D}_{0}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{D_{0}}{1+\gamma}) for small Î³ğ›¾\gamma. We briefly discussed this after Corollary 3.7.

Centralized SGD as a Special Case

Consider the case where Server has access to all training data of clients and thus can just perform local/centralized learning. This extreme case can be approximated by FSL using Î¾Â¯=0Â¯ğœ‰0\bar{\xi}=0 and a sufficiently large value of Î³ğ›¾\gamma. Since Corollary 3.7 is for Î³=ğ’ªâ€‹(1)ğ›¾ğ’ª1\gamma=\mathcal{O}(1), we can use Theorem 3.6 instead.

For large Î³ğ›¾\gamma, we have Îº=Î˜â€‹(Î³3)ğœ…Î˜superscriptğ›¾3\kappa=\Theta(\gamma^{3}). From (9), let us choose K0â€‹Î·0â€‹L=Î˜â€‹(1/Î³2)subscriptğ¾0subscriptğœ‚0ğ¿Î˜1superscriptğ›¾2K_{0}\eta_{0}L=\Theta(1/\gamma^{2}), which implies h=Î˜â€‹(Î³)â„Î˜ğ›¾h=\Theta(\gamma), Î¦=Î˜â€‹(Î³2â€‹Î¨)Î¦Î˜superscriptğ›¾2Î¨\Phi=\Theta(\gamma^{2}\Psi), and Î¨=Î˜â€‹(Î³2â€‹Ïƒ02K0+G~)Î¨Î˜superscriptğ›¾2superscriptsubscriptğœ02subscriptğ¾0~ğº\Psi=\Theta(\frac{\gamma^{2}\sigma_{0}^{2}}{K_{0}}+\tilde{G}) with G~=Ïƒ2Kâ€‹S+Ïsâ€‹G2S~ğºsuperscriptğœ2ğ¾ğ‘†subscriptğœŒğ‘ superscriptğº2ğ‘†\tilde{G}=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{KS}+\frac{\rho_{s}G^{2}}{S}. Let Î±=Î·0â€‹Î³ğ›¼subscriptğœ‚0ğ›¾\alpha=\eta_{0}\gamma, which is the stepsize of server in Algorithm 1. As a result, Theorem 3.6 implies â„°T=ğ’ªâ€‹(D~Tâ€‹K0â€‹Î±+Lâ€‹Ïƒ02â€‹Î±+G~Î³3)subscriptâ„°ğ‘‡ğ’ª~ğ·ğ‘‡subscriptğ¾0ğ›¼ğ¿superscriptsubscriptğœ02ğ›¼~ğºsuperscriptğ›¾3\mathcal{E}_{T}=\mathcal{O}(\frac{\tilde{D}}{TK_{0}\alpha}+L\sigma_{0}^{2}\alpha+\frac{\tilde{G}}{\gamma^{3}}). The first two terms are exactly the error bound of SGD with a fixed stepsize, and the last term is the contribution of clients, which is negligible for large Î³ğ›¾\gamma.

Appendix B Further Numerical Results

In this section, we present detailed models and further simulation results.

B-A Neural Network Models Used in Our Experiments

In our experiments, we use networks with 2 convolutional layers followed by 2 dense layers as shown in Tables II and III. Note that these models are enough for our purpose of illustrations and comparing different algorithms; they are by no means designed to achieve the state-of-the-art accuracy.

B-B Futher Results

B-B1 Test Accuracy Without Using Server Pretrained Model

Figure 6 shows the performance of FSL, FL and DS when they start from a randomly initialized model instead of a pretrained one as in FigureÂ 1. Clearly, in this case, the acceleration provided by SL is much more significant, even in the IID cases, in which DS offers little to no benefits as one would expect.

B-B2 Comparison with Non-incremental SL

FigureÂ 7 compares the performance of FSL, DS and the non-incremental version of SL, denoted by FSL-p, when varying Cğ¶C and Sğ‘†S. Clearly, FSL-p is slightly worse than DS while FSL significantly outperforms in all cases. A similar conclusion can be drawn as we vary Î³ğ›¾\gamma as shown in FigureÂ 8.

B-B3 Quantifying the Non-IIDness of Clients and Server

In general, it is difficult to obtain uniform bounds Î¾Â¯Â¯ğœ‰\bar{\xi} and GğºG in AssumptionsÂ 2â€“3. Thus, in FigureÂ 9, we show the following two related quantities in some of our experiments: Î¾t2=â€–âˆ‡f0â€‹(xt)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(xt)â€–2,superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“0subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2\xi_{t}^{2}=\|\nabla f_{0}(x_{t})-\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2}, and Gt2=1Nâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[N]â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(xt)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(xt)â€–2superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘¡21ğ‘subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¡2\textstyle G_{t}^{2}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in[N]}\|\nabla f_{i}(x_{t})-\nabla F(x_{t})\|^{2} for t=0,50,100,â€¦â€‹1000.ğ‘¡050100â€¦1000t=0,50,100,\ldots 1000. First, it is clear that increasing Cğ¶C reduces the non-IIDness considerably in our experiments with both datasets. Second, in most cases and on average, Î¾t2superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡2\xi_{t}^{2} is much smaller than Gt2superscriptsubscriptğºğ‘¡2G_{t}^{2} and is improved when n0subscriptğ‘›0n_{0} increases. Third, perhaps somewhat surprisingly, even having access to 2 or 5 samples per label (n0=90subscriptğ‘›090n_{0}=90 and 225225225) in EMNIST dataset already offers FSL a significant advantage to combat the non-IIDness of clientsâ€™ data. To have a similar level of benefit for the case of CIFAR-10, many more samples are needed for the serverâ€™s data. This is another indication besides final accuracy that in our experiments, EMNIST dataset is easier to learn from even though it has more label classes than CIFAR-10.

B-B4 Further Comparison with FedDyn and SCAFFOLD

Figures 10 and 11 show the test accuracy (averaged over 3 runs) of FSL, FSLsyn, FedDyn, and SCAFFOLD with server step size Î·g=Ssubscriptğœ‚ğ‘”ğ‘†\eta_{g}=\sqrt{S} and T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000. FSL, FSLsyn not only has comparable (if not better) final accuracy than SCAFFOLD in most cases but also achieves higher initial training acceleration.
